title: Martin Scorsese, Robert De Niro and Al Pacino open up about The Irishman
text:
The three men waltz into the room like three old friends coming together, not like the Herculean legends they’ve cemented themselves as in cinematic history.

First comes Martin Scorsese, then Al Pacino and finally Robert De Niro.

A clutter of publicists and assistants descend into the room before leaving as quickly as they came.

Scorsese is quoting lines from Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger's A Matter of Life and Death, as a fascinated Pacino listens on.

Al Pacino (left), Martin Scorsese (middle) and Robert De Niro (right) revealed what it was like to work together for the first time in their new movie The Irishman

Like Powell and Pressburger's 1946 fantasy movie, The Irishman delves into the extremes of life and death, but this time through the lens of a man who is recounting the grave decisions that shaped him.

In Scorsese’s story, the man coming to grips with his mortality is mafia hit man and Jimmy Hoffa associated Frank Sheeran (De Niro).

One of the principal subjects in the three-and-a-half-hour crime epic is time – something the three legends in the room are all well accustomed to.

Pictured: De Niro (left), Scorsese (middle) and Pacino (right) together while talking about their film

Scorsese said: ‘As they say in the movie, it’s gonna happen. We’re all human. We’re gonna die. The contemplative nature of it has to do with an accumulation of detail. Details, details.’

‘It’s a good thing for our culture to be able to take the time and experience it. You may like it, you may dislike it. But things move so fast now.’

‘We see the result of that in what’s happened to our country. We get a soundbite without context. People are too busy. It’s time to take time.’

And it took ages to get Scorsese, Pacino and De Niro together for a film.

The Irishman is their first film as a trio and that alone feel like a last salute to the ever-changing landscape cinema.

One where Scorsese’s kind of detailed, three-hour plus movies have all withered away to binge-ready entertainment.

De Niro pushed for The Irishman from the start after he became drawn to Charles Brandt’s book about Sheeran, ‘I Heard You Paint Houses.’

Pictured: De Niro as he appears during The Irishman trailer that stunned audiences with its age defying digital technology

To him, it held the potential to allow a more introspective peek into the world of organized crime that he, Scorsese, and Joe Pesci (who plays Mafia don Russell Bufalino) are so ingrained in.

It took a decade to see this vision onto the big screen and that’s in part due to the improved digital de-aging effects allowing actors to perform a lifetime.

It also didn’t hurt that Netflix backed the film with $159 million to create the film.

'We couldn’t have asked for anything more.’ De Niro said. ‘Period. That’s it.’

Pacino agreed, saying: ‘It really was an exceptional kind of situation. It was funny. Marty, there, Bob. It was so easy. It’s what we do.’

Pacino (right): 'It really was an exceptional kind of situation. It was funny. Marty, there, Bob. It was so easy. It’s what we do.'

And as the The Irishman received rave reviews at the New York Film Festival, the three men shared a moment of raw joy as they banded together for final bang on the gong.

Scorsese and De Niro have a long history of collaborations that ended in nine feature films, but it’s been quite a while.

Almost 24 years to the day the award winning, 1995 movie ‘Casino' released.

Somehow, Pacino never made a movie with Scorsese and he likens the experience to walking a high wire ‘only Marty was the net.’

The two man came close, though.

‘Al, I always wanted to work with. We met through Francis Coppola,' says Scorsese.

‘By the time other projects came up, I didn’t have the cachet, or certain types of stories, you had already covered the territory, like in "Scarface" or “Carlito’s Way”.’

Pacino says: ‘The big one I wanted to do — there was a lot of them — was the Modigliani.’

The Irishman released at the New York Film Festival to rave reviews and praise for the three men's direction and performance

Scorsese agrees the script was good, but he reminds Pacino that the 1980s was a time the director was struggling to find studios to support him.

Scorsese says: ‘What happened is that the whole industry changed. We opened “Raging Bull” nine or ten days before the same studio, UA, released “Heaven’s Gate”.’

‘And then “Heaven’s Gate” was closed by one review from The New York Times and that was the end of what’s derogatorily, unfortunately, referred to as the “auteur” cinema of America. It was destroyed.'

Scorsese begins to talk about the difficulties he faced getting ‘The Last Temptation of Christ’ made.

De Niro and Pacino play real life men - Frank Sheeran (right) and Jimmy Hoffa (left) who became involved with organized crime to fight the corruption of worker unions

It was initially cancelled a few weeks before shooting before its debut in 1988.

‘I took that as a voice shouting out to me, “Leave Los Angeles!” So I came back to New York and started over again,’ Scorsese says.

‘I saw that at the Ziegfeld,’ Pacino cuts in.

‘Amazing. They don’t have the Ziegfeld anymore.’

The loss of the iconic New York City movie theater in one of many things that has transformed for film making in the years since.

The Irishman is Scorsese’s second film with Netflix this year and, as he repeatedly explained, they were the only one’s willing to pay for it.

His new film is a poignant stake in Scorsese’s criticism of the movie landscape pandering to blockbuster-dominated Hollywood.

He believes movies are worth more than pacifying audiences.

‘It’s all been about servicing the audience and not challenging them. Challenging a bit — maybe more than a bit — enriches the audience. And it enriches our children. Don’t make the audience adolescent or childlike. The audience is ahead of you,’ Scorsese says.

Netflix will release The Irishman for a three-week exclusive run in theaters before dropping it on the streaming site on November 27.

Pictured: De Niro (left), Pacino (middle) and Ray Romano as Bill Bufalino (right) in The Irishman

Scorsese admits that The Irishman is more somber and subtle than his previous gangster movies "GoodFellas" or "Casino."

He says: ‘It may be in dialogue with those films. “GoodFellas” is on one level and “Casino” takes it another level. And that level ends it, in a way, at the end of “Casino”. It’s the end of that time and that enthusiasm for that world.’

On a different level than those films, The Irishman suggests there’s a world outside the greed, corruption and violence of earlier crime films – one not lost on De Niro, Pacino or Scorsese.

When they see each other, they say, their conversations aren’t hinged on movies.

'We talk about our kids,' says De Niro.

'It’s about living, really,' says Scorsese.

And: ‘How do I get a doctor in this city?,' adds Pacino as they all cackle.

'That’s the other thing!' Scorsese exclaims. '

Doctors, medication. Oh, you’ve got that, too! Oh no!'
description: Martin Scorsese, Robert De Niro and Al Pacino opened up about working together for the first time on Netflix's The Irishman, a movie following mafia hit man Frank Sheeran as he reflects on his life
